abstract:
1. A 250-word version

Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Nurses' Roles in Smoking Cessation Interventions

Background: Smoking poses significant health risks globally. Nurses are pivotal in smoking cessation interventions, yet their specific roles remain under-researched.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted using Arksey and O’Malley’s framework. A comprehensive search across ten databases, including PubMed and CINAHL, was performed, covering studies up to February 2024. Eligibility criteria included randomized controlled trials or quasi-experimental studies with nurse-led smoking cessation interventions. Data extraction was independently conducted by two reviewers, and findings were reported following PRISMA-ScR guidelines.

Participants: The study included patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) across various healthcare settings.

Intervention: Nurses employed motivational interviewing and the 5A method, distributing pamphlets and providing face-to-face education. The comparator involved standard care without nurse-led interventions.

Outcome: The primary outcome was smoking cessation rates, measured over a six-month period.

Randomisation: Participants were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Results: Of 53 studies, nurses were identified as assessors, educators, and practice facilitators. Smoking cessation rates improved significantly in the intervention group (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harm: No adverse events were reported.

Trial registration: OSF platform (https://osf.io/ba72e/).

Funding: Not specified.

Conclusions: Nurses play crucial roles in smoking cessation, yet pre-intervention training gaps exist, necessitating enhanced training programs.
